title: 211th Coastal Division (Italy)
text:
The 211th Coastal Division () was an <a href="infantry">infantry</a> <a href="Division%20%28military%29">division</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Italian%20Army">Royal Italian Army</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Royal Italian Army coastal divisions were second line divisions formed with reservists and equipped with second rate <a href="materiel">materiel</a>. They were often commanded by officers called out of retirement.
History.
The division was activated on 15 November 1941 in <a href="Cittanova">Cittanova</a> by reorganizing the XI Coastal Sector Command. The division was assigned to <a href="XXXI%20Army%20Corps%20%28Italy%29">XXXI Army Corps</a>, which was responsible for the defense of southern <a href="Calabria">Calabria</a>. The division was responsible for the <a href="Coastal%20defence%20and%20fortification">coastal defence</a> of southernmost part of the coast of <a href="Calabria">Calabria</a>: on the <a href="Tyrrhenian%20Sea">Tyrrhenian Sea</a> side from <a href="Capo%20Vaticano">Capo Vaticano</a> to the outskirts of <a href="Scilla%2C%20Calabria">Scilla</a>, on the <a href="Ionian%20Sea">Ionian Sea</a> side from <a href="Capo%20dell%27Armi%20Lighthouse">Capo dell'Armi</a> to <a href="Badolato">Badolato</a>.
Between 3 and 8 September the division skirmished with troops of British <a href="XIII%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">XIII Corps</a>, which had landed in southern Calabria in <a href="Operation%20Baytown">Operation Baytown</a>. After the <a href="Armistice%20of%20Cassibile">Armistice of Cassibile</a> was announced the division remained at its positions and surrendered to the British XIII Corps. Afterwards the division joined the <a href="Italian%20Co-belligerent%20Army">Italian Co-belligerent Army</a>, but did not participate in the <a href="Italian%20campaign%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Italian campaign</a>. The division was dissolved in summer 1944.
